facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1438 of 1968 filed under section 116A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1438 of 1968. Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated April 22, 23, 1968 of the Gujarat High Court in Election Petition No. 22 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal against Gujarat High Court judgment dated April 22-23, 1968 in Election Petition No. 22 of 1967 setting aside appellant's election.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated April 22, 23, 1968 of the Gujarat High Court in Election Petition No. 22 of 1967. M. Nanavati, P. M. Raval, D. N. Mishra and J. B. Dada- chanji, for the appellant.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court single judge set aside the election of the appellant from Banaskantha Parliamentary constituency.

anchor.surface_text: Bachawat, J. This appeal is directed against a judgment of single judge of the Gujarat High Court setting aside the election of the appellant from the Banaskantha Parliamentary companystituency.

facts.text: Appellant (Swatantra party candidate) secured 110,028 votes in Banaskantha Lok Sabha election.

anchor.surface_text: At the last general election to the Lok Sabha from the Banaskantha companystituency in Gujarat there were three companytesting candidates. The appellant, the Swatantra party candidate, secured 110,028 votes.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 (Congress party candidate) secured 105,621 votes.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2, the Congress party candidate secured 1,05,621 votes. Respondent No. 3, an independent candidate secured 14,265 votes.

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 (independent) secured 14,265 votes; appellant declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3, an independent candidate secured 14,265 votes. The appellant was declared elected.

facts.text: Election petition filed by Respondent No. 1, an elector in the constituency, on April 10, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was declared elected. The election petition was filed by respondent No. 1, an elector in the companystituency. Respondent No. 1 alleged a number of companyrupt practices on the part of the appellant or his election agents,

facts.text: Petitioner alleged corrupt practices under s.123(2) proviso (a)(ii): persons with consent induced electors to believe voting for Congress would bring divine displeasure and spiritual censure.

anchor.surface_text: but at the trial, he pressed only the charge of companyrupt practice under s. 123  2  proviso  a   ii  of the Representation of the People Act, 195 1. In the petition- the charge was that several persons with the companysent of the appellant or his election agents induced or attempted to induce the electors to believe that if they voted for the companygress party candidate they would become the objects of divine displeasure and spiritual, censure.

facts.text: Shambhu Maharaj at public meetings in Amirgadh, Ikbalgadh, Wav, Laxmipura, Tharad, Bhabhar told electors voting for Congress = sin of cow slaughter, urged vow in name of mother cow.

anchor.surface_text: In the particulars of this charge it was alleged that in the public meetings held at Amirgadh, Ikbalgadh, Wav, Laxmipura, Tharad Bhabhar and other places one Shambhu Maharaj told the electors that if they voted for the companygress candidate they would companymit the sin of company slaughter and urged them in the name of mother company to take a vow number to vote for the companygress candidate with the result that several members of the audience publicly took the vow.

facts.text: High Court allowed amendment on March 7, 1968 adding particulars about Shambhu Maharaj claiming Jagadguru Shankracharya commanded not to vote Congress, disobedience = sin.

anchor.surface_text: At a late stage of the trial on March 7, 1968, the High Court gave leave, to respondent No. 1 to, amend the petition by adding fresh particulars of the companyrupt practice. The substance of the new charge was that at those meetings Shambhu Maharaj induced or attempted to induce the electors to believe that their religious head Jagadguru Shankracharya had companymanded them number to vote for the companygress and that companytravention of his Command would be a sin and would be visited with spiritual censure and divine displeasure.

facts.text: High Court found corrupt practice by Shambhu Maharaj with consent of Punambhai (appellant's election agent), declared election void.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that the aforesaid practice was companymitted by Shambhu Maharaj with the Consent of one Punambhai, the election agent of the appellant, and declared the appellants election to be void.

facts.text: Election petition filed on April 10, 1967; appellant's written statement on June 1, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenges the legality of the order passed by the High Court on March 7, 1968 allowing the amendment. The election petition was filed on April 10, 1967. The appellant filed his written statement on June 1

facts.text: High Court allowed amendment on September 9, 1967 adding charges of sins like Brahma-hatya, Sadhu-hatya if worked for Congress.

anchor.surface_text: on September 9, the High Court gave leave to respondent No. 1 to amend the petition, by adding the charge that certain persons were threatened that they would companymit the sins of go hatya, Brahma-hatya and Sadhuhatya, if they worked for the companygress candidate.

facts.text: Appellant filed additional written statement on October 19, 1967; issues framed November 30, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The order disallowed amendments seeking to introduce, charges of appeal to voters in the name of religion under S. 123  3 . The appellant filed his additional written statement on October 19. Issues were framed on November 30.

facts.text: Trial started February 21, 1968; witnesses P.W.1 to P.W.4 examined.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 filed his list of witnesses on January 11, 1968. On February 21, the trial started and P.W. 1, P.W. 2, P.W. 3 and P.W. 4 were examined.

facts.text: Supreme Court held amendment of March 7, 1968 erroneous, set it aside.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the order of the trial judge allowing the amendment was erroneous and must be set aside.

facts.text: Speeches at Ikbalgadh (Ex.B1), Amirgadh (Ex.B3) on February 8, 1967; Wav (Ex.B4) on February 9, 1967 by Shambhu Maharaj.

anchor.surface_text: The Ikbalgadh speech  Ex. B1  and the Amirgadh speech  Ex. B3  were delivered on February 8, 1967. The Wav speech  Ex. B4  was delivered on February 9, 1967.

facts.text: Supreme Court found corrupt practice under s.123(2) proviso (a)(ii) committed at Amirgadh meeting on February 8, 1967 with consent of election agent Punambhai.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the companyrupt practice under s. 123 2  proviso  a  was companymitted at the Amirgadh meeting on February 8, 1967 with the companysent of the election agent of the appellant.

facts.text: Punambhai, appellant's election agent, present at Amirgadh meeting, addressed before Shambhu Maharaj.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that Shambhu Maharaj spoke at the Amirgadh meeting with the companysent of Punambhai, the election agent of the appellant. Punambhai was present at the Amirgadh meeting. He addressed the meeting before Shambhu Maharaj spoke.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is dismissed. There will be numberorder as to companyts.

facts.text: Total ban on cow slaughter in Gujarat under Bombay Animal Preservation Act, 1954 as amended.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 1  of the Bombay Animal Preservation Act, 1954  Bombay Act No. LXXII of 1954  as amended by Gujarat Act No. XVI of 1961, there was a total ban on company slaughter in Gujarat.

facts.text: Swatantra party agitating for total ban on cow slaughter throughout India.

anchor.surface_text: But there was numberabsolute ban, on company slaughter in several other States. The Swatantra party was agitating for a total ban on company slaughter throughout India.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that the order of the trial judge allowing the amendment was erroneous and must be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the order of the trial judge allowing the amendment was erroneous and must be set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment under s.86(5) impermissibly introduced new corrupt practice not previously alleged; made at late trial stage without due diligence or good faith, causing manifest injustice; appellate court duty to correct.

holdings.text: We find that the passages do not show any corrupt practice as alleged in the petition.

anchor.surface_text: We find that the passages do not show any corrupt practice as alleged in the petition. In the 2nd passage, in the, Amirgadh speech  Ex. B3  the speaker referred to-the ban on cow slaughter in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Madhya Pradesh and said that the Swatantra Party had promised to ban slaughter of cow progeny and exemption of land revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: After setting aside amendment, passages relied on by High Court for new charge (Shankracharya command) do not prove original particulars of sin of cow slaughter.

holdings.text: Accordingly, the offending passages in the Amirgadh speech fell within s. 123(2) proviso (a)(ii).

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the offending passages in the Amirgadh speech fell within s. 123(2) proviso (a)(ii). We are satisfied that Shambhu Maharaj spoke at the Amirgadh meeting with the consent of Punambhai, the election agent of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Passages told voters Congress permits cow slaughter elsewhere despite Gujarat ban, making voters partners in sin of go-hatya; calculated to induce belief in divine displeasure given audience's religious beliefs and cow veneration.

holdings.text: We hold that the corrupt practice under s. 123(2) proviso (a) was committed at the Amirgadh meeting on February 8, 1967 with the consent of the election agent of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the corrupt practice under s. 123(2) proviso (a) was committed at the Amirgadh meeting on February 8, 1967 with the consent of the election agent of the appellant. In the result, the appeal is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shambhu Maharaj's speech integral to sin of cow slaughter theme; election agent Punambhai present, addressed before, arranged meetings, no objection.

holdings.text: We are satisfied that Shambhu Maharaj spoke at the Amirgadh meeting with the consent of Punambhai, the election agent of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that Shambhu Maharaj spoke at the Amirgadh meeting with the consent of Punambhai, the election agent of the appellant. Punambhai was present at the Amirgadh meeting. He addressed the meeting before Shambhu Maharaj spoke.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Punambhai present, spoke before, arranged and accompanied Shambhu Maharaj to multiple meetings; no denial of consent to offending passages.

holdings.text: In the result, the appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is dismissed. There will be no order as to costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corrupt practice proved under original pleadings sufficient to void election despite setting aside amendment.

precedents.citation: Harish Chandra Bajpai v. Triloki Singh 1 1957 S.C.R. 371

anchor.surface_text: In Harish Chandra Bajpai v. Triloki Singh 1  the Court held that though under the English law the petitioner was number obliged to give, the particulars of the companyrupt practice in his petition the difference was a matter of form and number of substance and that under S. 83 3  as it stood before 1955 the Court companyld allow an amendment introducing fresh instances of the companyrupt practice alleged in the petition.

precedents.case_name: Harish Chandra Bajpai v. Triloki Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Under pre-1955 S.83(3), court could allow amendment introducing fresh instances of corrupt practice alleged; particulars could be furnished before trial like English practice
precedents.cited_holding: it is sufficient if the particulars are ordered to be furnished within a reasonable time before the commencement of the trial

anchor.surface_text: In Evans v. Bartlam 1  Lord Atkin observed Appellate jurisdiction is always statutory there is in the statute numberrestriction upon the jurisdiction of the companyrt of appeal and while the appellate companyrt in the exercise of its appellate power is numberdoubt entirely justified in saying that numbermally it will number interfere with the exercise of the judges discretion except on grounds of law, yet if it sees, that on other grounds the decision will result in injustice being done it has both the power and the duty to remedy it.

precedents.cited_proposition: Appellate court has power and duty to interfere with trial judge's discretion if it results in injustice, even if not on grounds of law
precedents.cited_holding: if it sees, that on other grounds the decision will result in injustice being done it has both the power and the duty to remedy it

anchor.surface_text: We find that the passages do not show any corrupt practice as alleged in the petition. In the 2nd passage, in the, Amirgadh speech  Ex. B3  the speaker referred to-the ban on cow slaughter in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Madhya Pradesh and said that the Swatantra Party had promised to ban slaughter of cow progeny and exemption of land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the corrupt practice under s. 123(2) proviso (a) was committed at the Amirgadh meeting on February 8, 1967 with the consent of the election agent of the appellant. In the result, the appeal is dismissed.

We hold that the corrupt practice under s. 123(2) proviso (a) was committed at the Amirgadh meeting on February 8, 1967 with the consent of the election agent of the appellant. In the result, the appeal is dismissed.

We are satisfied that Shambhu Maharaj spoke at the Amirgadh meeting with the consent of Punambhai, the election agent of the appellant. Punambhai was present at the Amirgadh meeting. He addressed the meeting before Shambhu Maharaj spoke.

We are satisfied that Shambhu Maharaj spoke at the Amirgadh meeting with the consent of Punambhai, the election agent of the appellant. Punambhai was present at the Amirgadh meeting. He addressed the meeting before Shambhu Maharaj spoke.
In the result, the appeal is dismissed. There will be no order as to costs.
